Award.AwardTitle: Testing the fidelity of neodymium isotopes as a paleocirculation tracer in the Southeast Indian-Southern Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration: In the modern open ocean neodymium (Nd) isotope values of seawater are often explained by the mixing of water masses. As such, Nd is recognized as a "quasi-conservative" tracer. Implicit in this "quasi-conservative" behavior is the assumption that no significant source of Nd exists along the water mass flowpath. This is the basic principle behind using Nd isotopes archived in marine sediments as a tracer of past ocean circulation. In recent years, several studies of Nd sources, sinks, and biogeochemical cycling has challenged this conventional wisdom and proposed additional sources of Nd, such as: (i) exchange with particulates that modifies seawater Nd isotope ratios, or (ii) addition of pore water Nd influenced by reactions with sediment. To successfully use Nd isotopes as a water mass tracer proxy, it is essential to understand these limitations. Therefore, this project will examine these alternative sources (and sinks) of Nd to evaluate their impact on the quasi-conservative behavior of seawater Nd. This research will help to constrain the limitations of Nd isotopes as a tracer of past ocean circulation. Funding supports career development for a postdoctoral researcher, provides field experience for a graduate student, and provides research experience for an undergraduate student.<br/><br/>Project investigators will collect samples that constitute the different components of modern Nd cycle (e.g., filtered seawater, water column particulates, pore waters and concurrent down hole sediment samples) during a cruise in the Southeast Indian-Southern Ocean (SEISO). The SEISO cruise track will: (i) cover major water masses of Southern Ocean origin (Antarctic Mode Water, Antarctic Intermediate Water, Upper and Lower Circumpolar Deep Water), (ii) extensively transit over the southeast Indian Ridge, and (iii) sample the region just north of the Subantarctic Front, where Subantarctic Mode Water is forming today. Seawater and pore water Nd isotopes and Rare Earth Elements will be analyzed, thereby allowing characterization of the Southern Ocean water masses, the effects on seawater Nd isotopes from potentially reactive ridge rocks, and the influence of pore water Nd flux on bottom water Nd isotopes. Besides improving the understanding of Nd cycling, data from this project will provide important information for interpreting other datasets from the research cruise, and will be of interest to a wide range of climate scientists as well as biogeochemical modelers, chemical and biological oceanographers, and polar scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nd isotopes are known to be used as a water mass tracer proxy, however, the global data distribution and water mass characterization with respect to Nd isotopes are not as wide spread. This is particularly true for the Indian Ocean where the data coverage is far from ideal. The Southeastern Indian and Southern Ocean (SEISO) is ideally situated where a large volume of Mode Water (MW), Antarctic Intermediate Water (AAIW), Lower Circumpolar Deep Water (LCDW), and Antarctic Bottom Water (AABW) enter from the Southern Ocean (SO). Moreover, the SO water masses in the SEISO cross substantial mid-ocean ridge systems and a major oceanic plateau (Broken Ridge) and basaltic rocks, which are often prone to Nd exchange. Thus, the main objective of this project has been to characterize the SO water masses entering the SEISO and evaluate the use of εNd as a universal water mass tracer. As part of the study design, we collected filtered seawater onboard R/V Thomas Thompson off Australia (between 31 S - 42 S) in the fall of 2018 (Figure 1A). 

Results (Figure 1B) indicate distinct εNd signature for different water masses entering the SEISO region with MW and AAIW exhibit εNd ~ -9 and ~ -10 east and west of the Broken ridge respectively, LCDW εNd ~ -9, and AABW εNd ~ -11.  The Indian Deep Water  is low oxygen water in the Indian Ocean with εNd  between - 7 and -8. The unradiogenic εNd values off old west Australian crust or the radiogenic materials off Broken Ridge have no significant effect on the water column dissolved Nd isotopes. While oxygen in ocean is not a conservative tracer, yet oxygen happens to be a good tracer of water masses in the Indian Ocean (similar to the Pacific). Interestingly, the water masses and their boundaries based on oxygen concentrations happen to mostly coincide with the water mass boundaries delineated by Nd isotope contours. This is a key observation which indicates that Nd isotopes are successfully tracking water masses in this part of the global ocean.
